BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Large and, in isolated cases, very large natural avalanches are possible.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The upper section of the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1000 m snow has fallen in some localities. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can over a wide area be released by small loads and reach medium size. In the course of the day these will increase in size additionally. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Restraint is advisable on this first sunny day. Dry slab avalanches are still to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, large wind slabs formed. Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released in some places by individual winter sport participants in particular on wind-loaded slopes.
Avalanches can be triggered in near-surface layers and reach quite a large size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
In particular above the tree line these avalanche prone locations are more widespread.

On very steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes more natural avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. The runout zones of avalanches capable of reaching the valley are to be treated with caution as well.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen thus far above approximately 2100 m. Thus far the wind has been strong in some localities.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area various wind slab layers are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
The meteorological conditions will facilitate a gradual strengthening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually. The weather conditions will foster a stabilisation of the near-surface layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the strong westerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed during the last two days. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The avalanches can in isolated cases reach large size. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1800 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, easily released wind slabs formed in the last two days. The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1600 m. The westerly wind has transported the new snow.
Up to 1900 m rain has fallen over a wide area.
In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. Dry avalanches are still possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed. Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released in some places by individual winter sport participants in particular on wind-loaded slopes.
Avalanches can be triggered in near-surface layers and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line.
Above the tree line the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.

On very steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes more natural avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen thus far above approximately 2100 m.
Thus far the wind has been strong in some localities. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly at elevated altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying. The upper section of the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The upper section of the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Slab avalanches are possible in isolated cases as before.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed in the last two days. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2400 m. More recent wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence.

Up to 2100 m rain has fallen over a wide area. In many places there is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. The westerly wind has transported the new snow.

In all altitude zones only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Above the tree line the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.

In particular on very steep slopes and in steep rocky terrain mostly small natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow has fallen thus far above approximately 2100 m. The wind was strong in some localities. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 1900 m only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain. As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will appreciably decrease.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2400 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the widespread mostly small wind slabs represent the main danger. Especially on steep sunny slopes medium-sized natural avalanches must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude brittle wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some fresh snow and in particular the sometimes deep wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects and above the tree line. The fresh wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. These can be released easily by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1000 m. The soft wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. Some fresh snow and in particular the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released easily, or, in isolated cases naturally in all aspects above the tree line.
Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 15 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1600 m. As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs will form in particular in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially on very steep slopes above approximately 2000 m.
At high altitude the wind slabs are larger.
Fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall on Friday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow of the last two days can be released easily or naturally in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The old snowpack will be prone to triggering in some places. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 1900 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted and weak.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall are lying on surface hoar in particular on shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are easy for the trained eye to recognise but prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. They are to be avoided as far as possible. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized. Even a small avalanche can sweep winter sport participants along and give rise to falls.

In addition further very occasional gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday. Over a wide area over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. As a consequence of the sometimes strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. The wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs require caution. The wind slabs remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs of the last few days are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow is lying on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 1200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In localities where more snow falls danger level 1 (low) will be reached in the evening.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the snowfall level drops the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses. Above approximately 1400 m and in gullies and bowls the danger of dry avalanches will increase a little to level 1 (low). In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to favourable bonding of the snowpack. Wind and new snow above approximately 1000 m. In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area up to 5 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes. The old snowpack will be quite stable.
